comments:
Second semester of a year-long design project. Design projects in various areas of bioengineering are chosen by the students with approval of the instructor in the Spring semester of the Junior year; a project brief, interim reports, a final report, and a presentation are required. Also emphasized are report writing, scheduling, project risk assessment, multidisciplinary environments and ethics.

Most students enjoyed this course very much; one noted expressed the majority opinion of students by saying “the format of the course is good, do not change anything!” Many, however, did express their frustration with not having more time to complete their presentations. Overall, most students “really enjoyed” this class. One student noted that he “learned so much about critical thinking, planning, team work, organization, and engineering.”

Students said that this class was “hard,” but enjoyable because “we got to pick our own area of study.” Some were concerned that the class involved too much paperwork and not enough time to actually do the work they were asked to do, but overall it was manageable.

Part of the senior year curriculum includes a year-long Senior Design research project that ensures all of our students learn to utilize fundamental engineering skills to solve complex medical problems. This course offers such hands-on research and/or design experiences under the supervision of a faculty member.

Overall, the course was described as difficult but enjoyable. Students were excited to pick their own areas of study, and learnt a great deal about “critical thinking, planning, team work, organization and engineering.” However, some expressed their concerns on the grading system was not transparent enough. Some noted that “the disconnect[ion] between the requirements of the course and the requirements to actually get a project done” affected their final grades.

The majority of students agreed that professors did a good job of helping students on their projects. And that the class was well-structured. Students reported that the “Council of Professors” was very helpful, but wished that the Gantt chart could have been replaced by something else. Some noted that “there didn’t seem to be any weeding out/validation by the professors” on the student-driven projects.

This course is required for BE students in the BSE program. It is intended for the spring semester of senior year, as a continuation of BE 495.

Second semester of a year-long design project. Design projects in various areas of bioengineering are chosen by the students with approval of the instructor in the Spring semester of the Junior year; a project brief, interim reports, a final report, and a presentation are required. Also emphasized are report writing, scheduling, project risk assessment, multidisciplinary environments and ethics.

Most students enjoyed this course very much; one noted expressed the majority opinion of students by saying “the format of the course is good, do not change anything!” Many, however, did express their frustration with not having more time to complete their presentations. Overall, most students “really enjoyed” this class. One student noted that he “learned so much about critical thinking, planning, team work, organization, and engineering.”

Professor Salinas was “thoroughly enjoyed” by most students. She was championed as “really approachable,” and students appreciated that they could go to her with questions.

Students said that this class was “hard,” but enjoyable because “we got to pick our own area of study.” Some were concerned that the class involved too much paperwork and not enough time to actually do the work they were asked to do, but overall it was manageable.
